verses.text: And Elihu continued, saying:
verses.comment: Elihu's speeches function as a bridge to God's direct answer in later chapters.

verses.text: "Bear with me a little longer, and I will show you; for I have yet more to say on God's behalf.
verses.comment: Elihu claims to speak for God, foreshadowing prophetic roles seen throughout salvation history.

verses.text: I will bring my knowledge from afar and will ascribe righteousness to my Maker.
verses.comment: Elihu aims to justify God, a foreshadowing of later doctrinal formulations of God's justice.

verses.text: For truly my words are not false; one perfect in knowledge is with you.
verses.comment: "One perfect in knowledge" may ultimately point forward to Christ, who embodies perfect wisdom. See Heb. 4:15.

verses.text: "Behold, God is mighty, and does not despise anyone; He is mighty in strength of understanding.
verses.comment: Elihu emphasizes God's might and impartiality. Compare Acts 10:34.

verses.text: He does not keep the wicked alive, but gives justice to the afflicted.
verses.comment: God's justice is both retributive and protective. Echoed in the final judgment. See Matt. 25:31–46.

verses.text: He does not turn his eyes away from the righteous, but with kings on the throne he sets them forever, and they are exalted.
verses.comment: The image of being set with kings anticipates the believer's royal priesthood. See 1 Pet. 2:9.

verses.text: And if they are bound in chains and caught in cords of affliction,
verses.comment: Earthly suffering can have a purpose in God's plan, purifying believers (cf. 1 Pet. 5:10).

verses.text: then He declares to them their work and their transgressions—that they have acted arrogantly.
verses.comment: God uses suffering to reveal sin—a theme picked up in the doctrine of purification and sanctification.

verses.text: He opens their ears to instruction and commands that they turn from iniquity.
verses.comment: Hearing and responding is central. Compare the call to repentance found in Matt. 4:17.

verses.text: If they obey and serve Him, they finish their days in prosperity and their years in pleasure.
verses.comment: Obedience brings blessings, which ultimately foreshadow the heavenly rewards (cf. Rev. 22:12–14).

verses.text: But if they do not listen, they perish by the sword and die without knowledge.
verses.comment: Disobedience leads to ruin, linking knowledge (faith) with salvation—emphasizing the importance of right belief and action.

verses.text: The godless in heart cherish anger; they do not cry for help when He binds them.
verses.comment: Hardened hearts resist grace—a continual biblical theme. See Heb. 3:7–8.

verses.text: They die in their youth, and their life ends among the cult prostitutes.
verses.comment: A reference to moral judgment. In the biblical worldview, moral decay leads to destruction.

verses.text: He delivers the afflicted through their affliction and opens their ear by adversity.
verses.comment: Suffering can be redemptive, a clear thread running to the New Testament: Rom. 5:3–5.

verses.text: He would have drawn you out of distress into a broad place where there is no constraint, and what is set on your table would be full of fatness.
verses.comment: Imagery of abundance is present; divine rescue leading to blessing. Broadly applicable to personal and spiritual salvation.

verses.text: But you are filled with the judgment due to the wicked; judgment and justice take hold of you.
verses.comment: Elihu warns Job against self-righteousness—a corrective needed for humility before God.

verses.text: Beware, lest anger lead you into scoffing, and let not the greatness of the ransom turn you aside.
verses.comment: Warning against losing faith in the mercy of God. 'Ransom' points forward to Christ’s redemptive work (cf. Mark 10:45).

verses.text: Will your cry for help, or all your strength, keep you from distress?
verses.comment: Human effort is insufficient. Divine grace is necessary—a principle seen throughout both covenants.

verses.text: Do not long for the night, when peoples are cut off in their place.
verses.comment: Reference to judgment and death. The believer is called to hope, not despair.

verses.text: Beware, do not turn to iniquity, for because of this you have been tested by affliction.
verses.comment: Affliction is a test, a theme fulfilled in the New Testament’s teaching on discipline and perseverance (Heb. 12:7–11).

verses.text: "Behold, God is exalted in His power; who is a teacher like Him?
verses.comment: God is ultimately the divine teacher, wisdom’s source—prefiguring the role of Christ as Teacher. See Matt. 7:28–29.

verses.text: Who has appointed Him His way, or who can say, 'You have done wrong'?
verses.comment: God's freedom and authority are absolute. The created cannot judge the Creator.

verses.text: "Remember to extol His work, of which men have sung.
verses.comment: Praise is an obligation flowing from God's works—modeled in worship practices since ancient times.

verses.text: All people have looked on it; man beholds it from afar.
verses.comment: God’s works are widely visible, even if not always understood—creation as a form of revelation.

verses.text: Behold, God is great, and we do not know Him fully; the number of His years is beyond searching.
verses.comment: God’s transcendence is emphasized here. Knowing God is always partial in this life, inviting humility.

verses.text: For He draws up the drops of water; they distill His mist into rain,
verses.comment: God's providence extends over nature—creation care is a constant theme in Scripture.

verses.text: which the clouds pour down and drop abundantly on mankind.
verses.comment: Reflects the generosity of creation, a sign of a gracious Creator.

verses.text: Can anyone understand the spreading of the clouds, the thunderings of His pavilion?
verses.comment: God’s mysterious ways are evidenced in creation—reinforcing divine wisdom.

verses.text: Behold, He spreads His lightning around Him and covers the depths of the sea.
verses.comment: Imagery of cosmic majesty reminiscent of theophanies (see Ex. 19:16–19).

verses.text: For by these He judges peoples; He gives food in abundance.
verses.comment: God's power both disciplines and provides, showing His fatherly care and righteous authority.

verses.text: He covers His hands with the lightning and commands it to strike the mark.
verses.comment: Shows God’s precise sovereignty over creation, underlining His omnipotence.

verses.text: Its thunder declares His presence; the livestock also declare when He rises.
verses.comment: Even creation announces the majesty of its Creator, echoing themes picked up in Romans 1:20 and elsewhere.
